trial_identification.studytitle: Pipelle for pregnancy in women undergoing single, autologous, embryo transfer
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial assessing the effect of endometrial pipelle biopsy vs. no intervention on live birth rate in women undergoing autologous embryo transfer.

interventions.interventions: Women randomised to the intervention arm will undergo a single endometrial pipelle biopsy performed between day 4 of the natural menstrual cycle preceding their embryo transfer cycle and day 3 of the menstrual cycle in which embryo transfer is planned
interventions.comparator: Women randomised to the control group will not undergo any treatment in addition to standard care. Standard care may involve aspects common to an IVF or embryo transfer cycle, such as hormonal down-regulation and ovarian hyper-stimulation, oocyte pickup, embryo transfer, luteal phase support etc.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Live birth - delivery of a live infant at least 20 weeks gestation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Clinical pregnancy - on ultrasound, the presence of at least one gestational sac
Ongoing pregnancy - on ultrasound, the presence of at least one gestational sac and heartbeat
Multiple pregnancy - on ultrasound, the presence of more than one heartbeat
Adverse events - including miscarriage, ectopic pregnancy, pain or bleeding following the procedure, infection etc.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Bleeding and pain: on the day of the procedure or the following day Infection: for 1 month following the procedure Ectopic pregnancy and miscarriage: up to 20 weeks following pregnancy

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Women planning to undergo autologous embryo transfer with any indication of subfertility
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Have had any disruptive instrumentation within the uterine cavity (e.g. hysteroscopy, hysterosalpingogram, laparoscopy, surgically managed miscarriage or endometrial biopsy) within three months prior to day one of the planned embryo transfer cycle, or planning to undergo a procedure involving disruptive instrumentation at any stage during the study. Embryo transfer and intrauterine insemination procedures are not considered to cause disruptive instrumentation 2. Entered previously into this study or participation in another trial in the last 30 days 3. Any contraindication to endometrial biopsy, being pregnant and/or carrying a pregnancy to term

trial_design.concealment: To ensure allocation concealment, randomisation of eligible individuals will be performed by an online randomisation system built into the data collection software.
trial_design.sequence: A computer generated block randomisation schedule, stratified for each fertility centre, will be created and protected by the database manager.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Bldg 14, Greenlane Clinical Centre Level 7/214 Green Ln W, Greenlane 1051

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Bldg 14, Greenlane Clinical Centre Level 7/214 Green Ln W, Greenlane 1051

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
A number of studies have been published which appear to show that performing an endometrial biopsy results in an increase in pregnancy and live birth rates.
Most of the studies have been conducted in a focussed subgroup of women, such as those with recurrent implantation failure, and there is little data available on the utility of endometrial biopsy prior to frozen-thaw embryo transfer.
To address these limitations, PIP-IVF is a pragmatic randomised trial recruiting all women undergoing autologous embryo transfer, and has been powered to allow detection of subgroup effects such women undergoing their first IVF cycle and women undergoing frozen-thaw transfers.
